notes.title: Primary Sources of Islamic Law: Qur'an, Sunnah, Ijma', Qiyas
notes.content: Define the four foundational sources and how they interact; differentiate revealed sources (Qur'an/Sunnah) from inferential sources (Ijma'/Qiyas). Typical exam asks: define + contrast, give examples, and mention limits of analogical reasoning.
keyTakeaways: Qur'an & Sunnah are naqli (transmitted) proofs; Ijma' & Qiyas are derived methods.
Schools vary on scope of Ijma' and mechanics of Qiyas.
Always support with an applied example (e.g., modern contracts).

resources.title: Britannica — Islam: Sources
resources.description: Overview of uṣūl (Qur'an, Sunnah, Ijma', Ijtihad/Qiyas)

resources.title: Wael Hallaq — An Introduction to Islamic Law (preview PDF)

notes.title: Ijtihad vs. Ijma' (Consensus) — Theory & Modern Relevance
notes.content: Define ijtihad as independent reasoning when explicit texts are silent/ambiguous; contrast with ijma' as binding consensus. Exams test definitions, authority, and contemporary applicability.
keyTakeaways: Ijtihad fills gaps but is constrained by usul; ijma' is a proof once established.
Debate exists over who constitutes the consensus body.
Use modern case studies (bioethics, finance) to show relevance.

notes.title: Istihsan, Istislah & Sadd al-Dhara'i — Secondary Principles
notes.content: Explain Hanafi istihsan (juristic preference), Maliki istislah (maslahah), and Sadd al-Dhara'i (blocking the means). Often asked to compare schools and justify usage.
keyTakeaways: Hanafis deploy istihsan to prevent hardship when strict qiyas is harmful.
Malikis emphasize public interest (maslahah mursalah).
Usage is disciplined by objectives (maqasid) and textual limits.

resources.title: Usul text — Principles of Islamic Jurisprudence (Part 2)

notes.title: Maqasid al-Shariah — Objectives Framework
notes.content: Define higher objectives (protection of faith, life, intellect, lineage, property). Exams ask concept, history (al-Ghazali, al-Shatibi), and modern applications (policy, finance, rights).
keyTakeaways: Maqasid guide interpretation where multiple lawful options exist.
Used to balance harms/benefits in modern governance.
Cite examples: consumer protection, privacy, poverty alleviation.

notes.title: Marriage as Civil Contract; Dower (Mahr) & Stipulations
notes.content: Nikah's contractual nature; essential elements (offer/acceptance, wali per school, witnesses), mahr types, and contractual stipulations benefiting wife.
keyTakeaways: Contractual view enables conditions (e.g., residence, education).
Mahr can be prompt/deferred; enforceable as debt.
Witnesses are key for proof/validity (school differences).

notes.title: Khulʿ in Pakistan: From Khurshid Bibi to Contemporary Doctrine
notes.content: Contrast classical requirements with Pakistan's case law (e.g., Khurshid Bibi (PLD 1967 SC 97)) expanding judicial powers to grant khulʿ without husband's consent if reconciliation fails.
keyTakeaways: Courts may decree khulʿ upon breakdown and return of mahr (where appropriate).
Compensation is not owed if husband is at fault (case-law trend).
Know difference between khulʿ and talaq-by-husband.

resources.title: IIUI Law Review — Case Law on Khulʿ (PDF)

notes.title: Talaq Forms (Ahsan, Hasan, Bid'ah) & Procedure
notes.content: Define recognized forms and procedural safeguards (notice mechanisms under MFLO). Discuss reconciliation, waiting periods, and abuses.
keyTakeaways: Ahsan preferred (single pronouncement + iddah).
MFLO mechanisms interact with classical forms.
Illegality of instant triple talaq in many systems (policy trend).

notes.title: Zihār & Liʿān — Classical Doctrines, Modern Status
notes.content: Define Zihār (forbidden assimilation to mother) and Liʿān (mutual imprecation in accusations of adultery/paternity). Exams ask definitions + Qur'anic basis + legal effects (atonement/separation).
keyTakeaways: Zihār requires kaffārah before resuming relations.
Liʿān dissolves marriage when proof is absent but accusation persists.
Know Qur'anic loci: Al-Mujādilah (58:1-4) for Zihār; Al-Nūr (24:6-9) for Liʿān.

notes.title: Dissolution of Muslim Marriages Act, 1939 — Grounds & Case Law
notes.content: List grounds for judicial dissolution (absence, failure to maintain, cruelty, etc.). Cite how Pakistani courts interpret and apply DMMA with MFLO.
keyTakeaways: DMMA operationalizes relief for wives in courts.
Grounds are enumerated; evidence & procedure matter.
Interplay with khulʿ and MFLO practice.

notes.title: Inheritance Shares & Testamentary Limits (Wasiyyah up to 1/3)
notes.content: Define fixed sharers vs residuaries; compute common scenarios; will may not exceed one-third and cannot benefit legal heirs (without consent).
keyTakeaways: Start by identifying heirs; allocate fixed shares; residue to 'asaba.
One-third cap for bequest; 'No bequest to an heir' rule (classical).
Practice calculations — frequent MCQ/short-note area.

resources.title: Hadith/Fiqh note — One-Third Rule (Sahih Muslim extract)
Academic chapter — Bequest may not exceed one-third

notes.title: Orphaned Grandchildren — Section 4 MFLO & Allah Rakha Case
notes.content: Explain representational succession under s.4 MFLO granting shares to orphaned grandchildren; discuss constitutional/sharia challenges culminating in Allah Rakha litigation and debates.
keyTakeaways: Section 4 provides for representation — a statutory reform.
Litigation questioned its conformity with Qur'anic scheme.
Know arguments on both sides and current status.

notes.title: Hudood Ordinances (1979): Zina & Property Offences
notes.content: Brief the Offence of Zina and Offences against Property Ordinances; elements, evidentiary thresholds, and later reforms. Exams ask definitions + distinctions between hadd and tazir frameworks.
keyTakeaways: Hadd requires stringent proof (e.g., witnesses/confession).
Hudood co-exist with tazir provisions; appellate review via FSC.
Cite criticisms & reforms in essays.

notes.title: Qisas, Diyah & Tazir — Penal Law Structure
notes.content: Distinguish retaliation (qisas), compensation (diyah), and discretionary punishments (tazir). Explain victim's role in qisas vs state role in tazir.
keyTakeaways: Qisas is victim-driven with options for forgiveness/compensation.
Tazir fills gaps where hadd/qisas do not apply.
Know examples and policy justifications.

notes.title: Riba in Pakistan — FSC Judgment (2022) & Transition Timeline
notes.content: Summarize FSC's 28 April 2022 decision declaring interest-based laws repugnant to Islam and setting direction for elimination with timelines.
keyTakeaways: FSC held all forms of riba prohibited; directed system shift.
Judgment influences banking/law reforms and litigation.
Cite official judgment + summaries.

notes.title: Shariah Governance in Islamic Banking (Pakistan)
notes.content: Governance architecture: Shariah Board, Resident Member, compliance & audit; compare with AAOIFI practices; useful for 'modern applications' essays.
keyTakeaways: SBP frameworks define roles & independence.
Ongoing updates (2014→2018→2024+).
Cite SBP circulars + peer-reviewed reviews.

notes.title: Constitution of Pakistan 1973: Islamic Provisions & FSC
notes.content: Preamble (Objectives Resolution), Art. 227 (Islamization mandate), Part IX (Islamic provisions), FSC chapter (Arts. 203-C to 203-J) — jurisdiction to test repugnancy.
keyTakeaways: Art. 227 requires conformity of laws to Qur'an & Sunnah.
FSC's decisions bind High Courts (subject to appeals).
Know how MFLO interacts with constitutional shields.

notes.title: Legal Capacity (Ahliyyah): Wujub vs Ada
notes.content: Define capacity to hold rights (ahliyyat al-wujub) vs capacity to act (ahliyyat al-ada); triggers (puberty/sanity) and disability categories (minority, insanity, coercion).
keyTakeaways: Capacity affects validity/enforceability of acts.
Exam asks definitions + examples (agency, contracts).
Cite classical usul texts + modern overviews.

notes.title: Iddah Rules & Rationale
notes.content: Waiting periods after divorce/death; wisdoms (lineage certainty, reconciliation window); connect to maintenance rules and remarriage restrictions.
keyTakeaways: Iddah length varies by cause (divorce vs death).
Rights during iddah (housing/maintenance per school).
Common short-note topic.

notes.title: Waqf — Legal Character & Public Benefit
notes.content: Endowment of property for perpetual charitable use; governance via mutawalli; relevance in essays on Islamic institutions and social welfare.
keyTakeaways: Inalienability & perpetuity are core features.
Supports education/healthcare historically.
Family waqf debates exist in modern reforms.

notes.title: Pakistani Family Law Framework — MFLO 1961
notes.content: Key sections: registration, polygamy control (s.6), talaq notice & reconciliation, inheritance reform (s.4). Essential statute for CSS questions.
keyTakeaways: MFLO adds administration & safeguards to classical rules.
S.6 regulates polygamy via Arbitration Council permission.
S.4 (representation) is tested often (see Note 11).

notes.title: Courts & Review: Federal Shariat Court (FSC) Jurisdiction
notes.content: FSC reviews laws for repugnancy to Qur'an & Sunnah; has Hudood appellate powers; decisions bind High Courts (subject to Shariat Appellate Bench).
keyTakeaways: Know Articles 203-C to 203-J structure.
Important for essays on Islamization & judicial review.
Quote Constitution directly for accuracy.

notes.title: Comparative Schools: Hanafi vs Shafi'i on Usul Highlights
notes.content: Spot-compare (qiyas scope, istihsan acceptance, 'urf role, sadd al-dhara'i). Useful for short notes and 'critically evaluate' prompts.
keyTakeaways: Hanafis: broader use of istihsan & 'urf.
Shafi'is: stricter on qiyas; skeptical of istihsan.
Always cite usul authorities when contrasting.

notes.title: Pakistani Constitutional Islamization — Article 227 Essays
notes.content: How Article 227 shaped legislation; Council of Islamic Ideology; Islamization waves (esp. Zia era). Use as backbone for long essays.
keyTakeaways: Art. 227 mandates conformity for present & future laws.
Islamization has institutional & political dimensions.
Support with academic sources + constitutional extracts.

notes.title: Contract Law in Islamic Jurisprudence — Consent & Capacity
notes.content: From usul view: conditions for valid 'aqd (offer/acceptance, subject, consideration, capacity); examples: sale, lease, agency.
keyTakeaways: Ahliyyah determines validity (void/voidable).
'Urf (custom) can inform contract terms.
Apply to modern forms (e-contracts, banking).

notes.title: Short-Notes Bank: Terms Repeated in Papers
notes.content: Quick definitions usually asked for 5–10 marks: Nushūz, Taklīf, Amr/Nahy, Khulʿ, Zihār, Liʿān, Talaq-i-Ahsan, Musharakah.
keyTakeaways: Memorize 2-3 line definitions with one citation.
Add one modern application example where possible.
Cross-link with longer answers for coherence.

notes.title: Video Practice — Inheritance Calculations
notes.content: Use worked examples to solidify Faraid; practice common family trees; check against calculators for accuracy.
keyTakeaways: Start with fixed sharers, then residuaries.
Practice with varying heirs (kalalah cases).
Keep one-third will rule in mind.

notes.title: Exam Essay Pattern — Modern Issues (Human Rights, Finance)
notes.content: Structure essays linking maqasid to human rights discourse and financial regulation; use FSC riba judgment and SBP governance as contemporary anchors.
keyTakeaways: Open with maqasid framing; analyze case/statute; conclude with policy.
Quote precise articles/sections (credibility boost).
Balance classical doctrine with Pakistani context.

notes.title: Study Videos — MFLO 1961 (Full Course-Style Lectures)
notes.content: Use lecture series to cement statutory sections, procedures, and case-law illustrations; helpful for quick refreshers before mock exams.
keyTakeaways: Map videos to statute sections (s.4, s.6, talaq notices).
Take timestamped notes for revision.
Pair with bare-act reading.
